@mistercrunch I'm fixing tests, but I don't understand how SQL lab `alerts` worked previously, they aren't used by any sqllab component, they are only defined in App as a proptype, referenced in redux logic, and they don't seem to feed into the previous `AlertsWrapper`.

Thoughts?

@mistercrunch @graceguo-supercat this should be good to go.

I made sure `flash_messages` are displayed, but I'm not sure that it works correctly because of the way we cache sqllab redux state. when I force the backend to add flash messages (they appear in the bootstrap data), the empty messages array from the previous state takes precedence and none are displayed. in any case, this was probably broken before (and still unsure about `alerts`, from my question above. any thoughts @mistercrunch ?)
@mistercrunch I have cherry picked your changes and again merged the change, Thanks for pointing it.

did you configure the superset db charset? e.g.
`mysql://{user}:{passwd}@{host}:{port}/{db}?charset=utf8`

@mistercrunch I have the same confusion. I assumes that `database` access control will provide all the datasource access if tables were within that `database`. If a slice's datasource is from this specific database, then I will be able to access this slice. If a dashboard's datasources are within this specific `database`, then I will be able to access this dashboard.

@mistercrunch It seems like the issue is the running of the JDBC driver jar. A new JVM gets created for each connection, instead of threads being added to one running JVM. I think it has something to do with SQLAlchemy wanting one thread per process.
Is it resolved? I am also facing the same issue when querying. My data is on BigQuery. In sql lab it shows on how exactly it should but it shows unix timestamp in Bar Chart visualization
@mistercrunch  anything left to be done here? Looking forward to this feature. Thanks!
Cool, I'll put up a PR this upcoming weekend

@yamyamyuo I wanted my Superset dash to update every 24h, and I don't know enough JS to let the user set the interval :)

Maybe you want to build the feature to let the user set the interval? I'm imagining something like a horizontal slider might be a good design.
Submitted a PR
üèì

@miloradkrstevski The first step would be to profile the queries Superset is submitting to the db. It sounds like Superset may not be using any of your indexes. The specific indexes and configurations needed will depend on your schema and integration, but a great place to start is looking at the `where` clause of Superset queries.
:ship:
Any update
üêë
üêë
hitting this issue with superset version 0.26.3 and pyhive 0.6.0; please assist

@mistercrunch Is there any difference between about sql query process between sql lab and exploring chart, I find the time consumings of same sql statment in two places  are totally different, and some sql statment in sql lab is time-out.

I have a similar problem with cache_timeout

### **Superset version**
0.23.0dev

### **Expected results**
It seems setting cached timeout means to get data again from datasource and rebuild the slice too. 

### **Actual results**
Slice timeout setting is never used

### **Steps to reproduce**
I set cache timeout for the data source equal to 1 seconds and in `NVD3TimeSeriesViz` I add a line 
`cache_timeout=5`
Then I created a table in an SQLite database that is updating every 5 seconds and I also create a slice with type `Time Series - Line Chart`. The slice cannot update itself every 5 seconds. I have to press **run query** button to update it.

But exporting a table as a csv works without enabling the popups. Exporting dashboards should also work this way.
Yeah that sounds good. Can you elaborate your thinking on cascading filters? What do you mean by "maybe a whitelist blacklist approach"?

Also worth pointing out, the documentation/comments in `config.py` are unclear on the difference between the two variables. If there is a need for having separate variables, their differences need to be clearly stated in `config.py`.
@timifasubaa I think so, but I'm not familiar with the history of the variables, especially why `SQL_MAX_ROW` was originally split in two (see #3139).

I see. There have been 2 attempts at limiting query results. One at the query level and the other at the display level. 
At the query level, we have tried to wrap the user query with another query so it will look like `select * from (user_query) limit sql_lab_row_limit; Now we parse the sql and change the limit in place or add a limit if none was specified. 

The second attempt is to only get a subset of the results from the results backend to send to the frontend. That's the display limit. As seen here (https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blame/a17f7141b75f4aca2458d3190ad92f96840ccbcd/superset/views/core.py#L2480) 

Now most of the work is done on the backend by modifying the query so it should be fine using the same variable. 

I recommend we use `SQL_MAX_ROW` across the board and set it to 1000.
Agreed @timifasubaa, this looks much better.

Looks like Dremio has an ODBC driver and a SQLAlchemy dialect (https://github.com/sqggles/sqlalchemy_dremio), which means something like: `dremio+pyodbc://malsmith:XXXXXXXXXX@mydremio` may work.

You may have to add a new entry to configure Dremio in `superset/db_engines_sepc.py`, and depending on the maturity of the SQLA dialect you may need to tweak that as well.

Does that happen on the second concurrent command only? Why running 2 instances on the same machine?
I want two frontends of superset, one the default one and the other one I want to do some adjustments in the frontend.

The preferred way is to go through SQLAlchemy when possible, otherwise you can look at what's under `connectors/` there's a set of base classes you'd need to implement, and 2 implementations for `druid/` and `sqla/`
Sounds like this become more of a Gunicorn question: "How can I run 2 Gunicorn instances on one box"
It looks like this causes an error `pylint: error: no such option: -v`, after that's resolved this lgtm
